attack /əˈtæk/
To attack something is to hurt or damage it.
She watched the lizard attack its prey.
breast /brest/
A breast is one of the two soft parts on a woman's chest.
She was diagnosed with breast cancer.
cancer /ˈkænsər/
Cancer is a serious disease that causes cells to grow abnormally.
He was a leading scientist in finding a cure for cancer.
cancerous /ˈkænsərəs/
Cancerous cells are the result of cancer.
The exam found cancerous cells in the patient's blood.
cell /sel/
A cell is the smallest part of a living thing that can live by itself.
A red blood cell carries oxygen.
cigarette /ˈsɪɡəret/
A cigarette is a thinly wrapped paper tube filled with tobacco that is smoked.
Cigarette smoking is terrible for your health.
code /kəʊd/
A code is a set of symbols used to hide or read a message.
She used the code to solve the puzzle.
cure /kjʊr/
A cure is a medical treatment to make a sickness go away.
Scientists are still working on finding a cure for diabetes.
destruction /dɪˈstrʌkʃn/
To damage something is to cause its destruction.
The wildfires left the forest in a state of destruction.
DNA /díːènéi/
DNA is the short form of deoxyribonucleic acid.
The police sometimes use DNA to solve crime.
extensive /ɪkˈstensɪv/
Extensive means large in size or amount.
The game drew extensive media coverage.
female /ˈfiːmeɪl/
Female refers to women or girls.
She is the only female student in her class with short hair.
furthermore /ˌfɜːrðərˈmɔːr/
Furthermore means more information will be added.
She's clever, and furthermore, she is not afraid of work.
gene /dʒiːn/
A gene controls what it looks like, how an organism grows, and how it develops.
Gene therapy is sometimes used to treat an illness.
inherit /ɪnˈherɪt/
To inherit is to receive something that is passed down from a relative.
All the girls in my family inherit red hair from my great-grandmother.
link /lɪŋk/
A link is a connection to something else.
The two lines in the poem share a common link.
male /meɪl/
Male refers to men or boys.
He was the only male in the store.
population /ˌpɑːpjuˈleɪʃn/
A population is all the people living in an area.
The population of our city is steadily growing.
result /rɪˈzʌlt/
A result happens because of something else.
The result of her experiment was surprising.
sugar /ˈʃʊɡər/
Sugar comes from plants and is used to make food taste sweet.
She added extra sugar to her tea.
